SENT.plain: A novel fluorescence probe, 2-[6-(4'-hydroxy) phenoxy-3H-xanthen-3-on-9-yl] benzoic acid (HPF) was used to investigate the generation of highly reactive oxygen species (hROS) under ischemia both in vitro and in vivo

In the in vitro study, HT 22 cells were used to demonstrate that was predominantly detected in the cytoplasm, which coincides with the location of the mitochondria and then its HPF fluorescence gradually increased from 6 to 24 h due to glutamate induced oxidative stress
In the in vivo study, the permanent and transient middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) was induced in rats
Brain slices were incubated in an artificial medium containing HPF
The area of enhanced HPF fluorescence existed in both the ischemic core and the peri-infarct area at 4h after MCAO in both permanent and transient MCAO models
The area extended beyond the boundary of the ischemic damage into biochemically viable tissue
The enhanced fluorescent intensity following transient MCAO was higher than that observed in the permanent MCAO model
Hydroxyl radical scavenger, MCI-186 significantly suppressed the enhanced fluorescence intensity
This study demonstrated that HPF has a high sensitivity and specificity for the detection of hROS in focal cerebral ischemia as well as in a cellular model of oxidative stress
